case_vignette: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician 3 months after noticing skin changes on his scalp. When he scrapes off the crust of the lesion, it reappears after a few days. Occasionally, his scalp itches or he notices a burning sensation. He had a mole removed on his right forearm 5 years ago. He is a retired winemaker. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple rough patches on his scalp. A photograph is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient reports experiencing skin changes on the scalp, with recurrent crusty patches that itch and burn. The rough patches have been persistent for the past 3 months and keep reappearing a few days after being scraped off. The patient had a mole removed from the right forearm 5 years ago and denies any other recent changes besides the recurrent rough patches on the scalp. There are no new changes besides the persistent rough patches, and the patient has not noticed any other changes. No family history of skin conditions or autoimmune diseases is reported.
trial_0.summarized_mcq: The most likely diagnosis is Tinea capitis.
trial_0.summarized_frq: The most likely diagnosis is seborrheic dermatitis.
